data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Trust Board recognises the importance of ensuring that all Trust Staff are able to deliver service in the safest way for both themselves and the patients they care for. All staff including bank staff, fixed term staff and external contractors, together with the Trust's governors, volunteers and Board members are responsible for undertaking the levels of statutory and mandatory training identified for their role.

By actively managing the participation of all staff in the appropriate training as outlined by the Trust, the Trust aims to ensure that it complies with both legislative and regulatory requirements as well as achieving its overall goal of providing competent and capable workforce which are able to deliver excellent care for the patients they look after.

This ensures that all who work at the Trust have the levels of professional competence needed to deliver their services. It also means that the Trust offers a safe environment for all of its patients, staff and visitors.
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to document the process for ensuring a systematic approach to management of training for all staff and detail how that is implemented and monitored in practical terms:
To set out the minimum training (both subject and frequency)that all staff must undertake to sufficiently mitigate risk to the Trust and its patients and service users
Set out the objectives and processes required to underpin Statutory & Mandatory Training
Provide the governance structures and define the accountabilities, roles & responsibilities for all employees in terms of Statutory & Mandatory Training
Outline the processes for identifying , designing and maintaining Statutory & Mandatory Training
It is recognised that regular training beyond that which is laid out this in this document is required for specific groups of professionals in order to maintain professional registration.

The details of those requirements are outlined with the standards for those professionals. To ensure all Staff receive relevant and timely risk management education in relation to the role they are fulfilling
To ensure the Trust is compliant with all relevant professional guidelines and guidance in relation to risk management training.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
All Staff - are responsible for:

Ensuring that they attend all relevant mandatory training in line with the role they are employed in and are compliant with the special arrangement put in place with the suppliers of agency and locum staff they complete other training that has been identified in the risk assessment of their role
Participating fully in the training sessions
To register their attendance at face to face courses in the training programme outlined in this policy by signing the registers provided by the course leader/training
Cancelling bookings in advance, with reasonable notice, should attendance no longer be possible
Rebooking training and attending the rebooked session
Providing reasons for DNA's
Keep ESR Updated when changing Job or Management
Agency/Locum Staff - have the duty to:
Ensure they are compliant with the special arrangements for training put in place with the suppliers of agency and locum staff
Managers - have the duty to:
Release staff from their duties in order to participate in the appropriate training
Review and maintain statutory mandatory training compliance within their Team
Annually review all staff compliance at annual appraisal
Ensure all staff, including bank staff and external contractors that they manage, are compliant with the Trust's overarching Statutory/Mandatory Training
Ensure that all clinical staff have met the Trust's overall levels of clinical training
Support the booking/participation of training for those staff without easy access to the Trust Learning Management System
Ensure that ESR is updated with staff and management changes for the areas they manage.
Performing a risk assessment of all staff that they manage including bank staff and external contractors as required.
Concerns should be raised with Staff bank for any agency or locum staff that fail to complete or keep up to date with training provided by the Trust or rd party.

For permanent staff that fail consistently to attend training whilst being released from the work area, appropriate action should be taken with the member of staff to emphasise the importance of statutory and mandatory training
The Chief Executive, Chief Nursing Officer, Chief Medical Officer, Chief of People and Organisational Development Officer – have the duty to:
To agree to the programme of training as outlined within this policy
To actively support the communication and implementation of this policy as the professional lead for all Staff within the Trust
To act and address non adherence of this policy amongst MSE Staff
To act as necessary to ensure non-adherence with the policy amongst all staff within the Trust is addressed
To ensure sufficient Trainers/Subject Matter Experts and adequate resources are provided to maintain the delivery of the programme outlined within this policy.
Subject Matter Experts (SME's) have the duty to:

Undertake an annual review (more frequently if there are changes to legislation and local or national drivers) of content of Statutory / Mandatory training and the associated Training Need Analysis (TNA), ensuring input from all stakeholders.
Advise People & OD of any changes that impact on compliance requirements for example duration of sessions, frequency, staff group requirements etc.
Work with managers to support their local training plans
Follow up any constructive feedback from staff undertaking Statutory / Mandatory Training.
Digital Learning Team has the duty to:
To provide a process for communicating the availability of training to all staff via The Learning Management System
To provide a process for all staff to book onto courses and access online learning via The Learning Management System
Ensure participation of all staff in the programme of training data is available as outlined in this policy
To liaise with the SME's and Statutory/Mandatory Training Directorate representatives regarding target groups changes and queries
Key elements of policy
This policy applies to all staff at the Trust (permanent - full/part time, fixed term or Staff Bank, Locums contracted to work for a period of six months or longer)

Statutory / Mandatory training is reviewed yearly as a minimum to ensure content keeps pace with the emerging organisational and statutory context. Content where applicable is aligned to the Core Skills Training Framework (CSTF) and is reviewed on an ongoing basis by the relevant Subject Matter Leads to ensure sessions remain relevant, contemporary, and represent best practice.
All employees must complete Statutory / Mandatory training; the extent and content will be based on the complexity and duties of their role.

The expectation of the Trust is that all staff will undertake the e-learning on site during their normal working hours, however, in the event where staff have to undertake this training outside their contracted hours, will acquire Time off in Lieu (TOIL). Guidance for such arrangements is stated in Appendix
Managers are accountable for ensuring that they have a local plan that identifies the training requirements of their staff, and have a record of their training attendance
The policy does not cover non-risk management training, for example, management development, continuing education and training relating to registration of certain professional groups
Training requirements
Development of the Trust's training needs analysis

There are a number of topics that the Trust has decided is mandatory for certain groups of staff in line with NHS Litigation Authority (NHSLA), Care Quality Commission (CQC), Core Skills Training Framework and other governance arrangements. These topics listed below forms the basis of the Trust's training needs analysis (TNA).
The topics that are as a requirement for all NHS organisations in line with the CSTF are identified as core topics on this document.
All new topics identified by the SME's as mandatory training must be raised at the Statutory and Mandatory Steering Group for approval prior to the topic being added to the training needs analysis.

To aid the development of the training matrices, the Digital Learning Team, in collaboration with key operational training leads have identified a number of key staffing groups in order to provide greater clarity for interpretation, implementation and monitoring purposes. See appendix 3 for how the key staffing groups have been derived with examples

To aid the development of the training matrices, the Digital Learning Team, in collaboration with key operational training leads have identified a number of key staffing groups in order to provide greater clarity for interpretation, implementation and monitoring purposes.
The key staffing groups relate to the type of role individuals are employed to do and are based on national Job roles for NHS staff.
The SME's identify the frequency requirements for all training courses based on the guidance given by the relevant regulatory body.

These key staffing groups have then been sub-divided to reflect the specific roles in the area of the Trust in which individuals work so that training needs can be identified more specifically. From this point, the needs of each individual staff group are assessed by the Statutory/Mandatory Training Directorate representatives who confirm the finalised target groups for the mandatory training topic.
Acceptance of external Stat/Man training records from other organisations
The Trust will accept external training records for all CSTF (Core Skills Training Framework) topics excluding Fire, as listed in section 6.1.
The records must meet the following requirements:

Only records from CSTF aligned organisations that are aligned for the topic will be accepted. This ensures that the training accepted meets the Trust's standards (See website for details on organisations that are aligned: http://www.skillsforhealth.org.uk/services/item/146‐core‐skills‐training‐framework).
The organisation where the training was obtained must be shown clearly on the record
All records transferred via Inter Authority Transfer(IAT) from other NHS Trusts will be accepted irrespective of expiry date

Where non-IAT records that are manually provided from organisations aligned with the CSTF, the validity requirement will be reduced to a minimum of 3 months till it expires if the records are not transferred via an ESR IAT.
Criteria for Non IAT Documentation:
The trust will accept non IAT documentation dependant on the following requirements:
The documentation must include the full name of the individual

The documentation must state what training has been covered. Where topics differ to the training title used by Mid and South Essex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, the individual will be asked to confirm that the contents of the training meets the same level of compliance as required by MSEFT. Individuals will be responsible for the validity of the confirmation they provide. Exceptional circumstances for acceptance of records outside the agreed criteria listed in this policy must be approved in writing by the relevant Executive responsible for the area in question.
New mandatory training requirements
If managers wish to introduce a new mandatory training course to staff within the Trust, the following process should be undertaken:
A proposal should be submitted to the Workforce Governance Sub Group setting out the following pieces of information:
Why the training is required:
What the training entails
What benefits the training will achieve?
Who the training applies to
The frequency of training
6.14.1 The duration of training:
The proposed method of delivery i.e., classroom / eLearning
Who will deliver, if it is not e-learning
References e.g., NSF requirement / Professional Body recommendation etc.

The Statutory Mandatory Group will consider the request and make a recommendation to the Operational Management Board for approval. Training will not be included in the mandatory training programme until final approval has been granted and then added to the Training Needs Analysis and course prospectus, if applicable.
Follow-up of non-attendance and persistent non-attendance

It is anticipated that on occasion as a result of exceptional work volumes or unplanned absence, members of staff booked onto training may fail to attend the session they are booked on. In the first instance, if time allows, the staff members should update the Learning Management System (LMS) to reflect that they will be unable to attend. If this is not possible, the Course Leader/Trainer will record the Staff members absence on the Learning Management System as a ‘Did not attend' (DNA). Where the absence is due to exceptional work pressures, then the manager / in charge should notify the course leader/trainer.

The system will notify the line manager of any member of staff who DNAs and the attendee, requesting an explanation for the DNA and that they are rebooked as soon as possible onto another session of the training. The training leads should input any reasons for non-attendance into Learning Management System and the Learning Management System Team will then monitor responses received.
DNA rates will be documented in the reports to the Workforce Governance Meeting.

All staff are required to ensure they complete the required training within the defined frequency. Failure to maintain their training will, in the first instance, result in their access to additional non-statutory/mandatory training being blocked until such time as they have completed the required Statutory/Mandatory training. Continued failure

to complete the required training or provide evidence of a rationale explanation will be reflected in the individuals staff members performance review and may therefore impact on any reward. Where persistent non-attendance occurs or programmes are consistently incomplete, staff names will be escalated to Site Leadership Teams

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Statutory Mandatory Steering Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve recommended changes in local and national guidance on training provision within the Trust\ NHS or Statute. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Statutory and mandatory steering group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
This policy will be reviewed annually unless earlier review is required as a result of internal or external developments.
